title: 106_s2092
content:
Modification of authorities regarding the use of pen registers and trap and trace devices. The amendment to Section 3121(c) of title 18, United States Code expands the use of pen registers and trap and trace devices by governmental agencies. It includes changes to the processing and transmitting of wire and electronic communications. Additionally, the amendment allows for the issuance of ex parte orders authorizing the installation and use of these devices upon application and certification by the Government attorney. The court can authorize the installation and use of pen registers or trap and trace devices for ongoing criminal investigations. The order applies to any entity providing communication services in the US. The State law enforcement officer must certify that the information obtained is relevant. The legislation is amended to include a description of the communications to which the order applies, including identifiers and locations of the telephone line or facility, and geographic limits for trap and trace device use. The legislation allows for the installation of pen registers or trap and trace devices for criminal investigations, with specific requirements for nondisclosure and emergency installations in cases of national security threats or public health and safety concerns. SEC. 2. MODIFICATION OF PROVISIONS RELATING TO FRAUD AND RELATED ACTIVITY IN CONNECTION WITH COMPUTERS. Penalties under section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include exceptions in subparagraphs (B) and (C) and to modify offenses punishable under subsection (a)(2). Subparagraph (C) is removed and replaced. The penalties under section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include exceptions and modify offenses punishable under subsection (a)(2). Subparagraph (C) is replaced with new provisions for fines or imprisonment up to 10 years for certain offenses causing financial loss or medical harm. The penalties under section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include exceptions and modify offenses punishable under subsection (a)(2) to address various forms of harm, including physical injury, threats to public health or safety, and damage to government computer systems. The definitions in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include new terms such as 'damage' and 'conviction'. The term 'loss' in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, includes costs incurred by victims, such as responding to an offense and restoring data. Damages in civil actions are limited to loss unless specific elements are present. Additionally, the court must order criminal forfeiture for individuals convicted of violating this section. The court, in case of a violation, can order the forfeiture of any property used in the offense or obtained from it. The process will follow the Controlled Substances Act, except for a specific subsection. Civil forfeiture is also applicable as per the amended section. The court can order the forfeiture of any property used in or obtained from a violation. Civil forfeiture applies to property used to commit or derived from violations. SEC. 3. JUVENILE DELINQUENCY.

Amends section 5032 of title 18, United States Code to include additional felony violations related to section 1030 of this title.

SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO SENTENCING GUIDELINES.

Amends section 805(c) of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 to specify felony violations of paragraph (5)(A).
